articles.headline: Militants’ Siege on Mountain in Iraq Is Over, Pentagon Says
articles.snippet: Defense officials said that American airstrikes and Kurdish fighters had broken the Islamic militants’ siege of Mount Sinjar, allowing thousands of the Yazidis trapped there to escape.
articles.abstract: Defense officials said that American airstrikes and Kurdish fighters had broken the Islamic militants’ siege of Mount Sinjar, allowing thousands of the Yazidis trapped there to escape.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Department officials said late Wednesday that United States airstrikes and Kurdish fighters had broken the Islamic militants’ siege of Mount Sinjar, allowing thousands of the Yazidis trapped there to escape.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Smartphones Overstate Their Social Intelligence
articles.snippet: With access to our calendars, contacts and location, phones should be able to communicate with great intelligence, but often buzz at just the wrong time.
articles.abstract: With access to our calendars, contacts and location, phones should be able to communicate with great intelligence, but often buzz at just the wrong time.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a smartphone app wants to alert you to a coming appointment, a text message or some bit of breaking news from your social network, it sends a tiny flare that lights up your phone’s lock screen. Depending on how you’ve set it up, the app might then buzz your pocket like a manic bee, sound a citywide panic alarm or begin playing “La Cucaracha.”

articles.headline: Gift of GQ Magazine Prompts Outcry From Lands’ End Customers
articles.snippet: Some Lands’ End shoppers were none too pleased to receive a free copy of GQ that featured a model posing topless except for a strategically placed lei.
articles.abstract: Some Lands’ End shoppers were none too pleased to receive a free copy of GQ that featured a model posing topless except for a strategically placed lei.
articles.lead_paragraph: The free magazine was meant as a gift from Lands’ End — the retailer known for its conservative, sturdy clothing — to its most valued customers.
articles.byline: By Leslie Kaufman and Christine Haughney

articles.headline: Anonymity in Police Shooting Fuels Anger in Missouri
articles.snippet: In the days since an unarmed man was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., the selective release of information, and especially the anonymity granted the officer, has stoked frustrations.
articles.abstract: In the days since an unarmed man was killed by a police officer in Ferguson, Mo., the selective release of information, and especially the anonymity granted the officer, has stoked frustrations.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — In the five days since an unarmed young black man was fatally shot by a police officer here, the selective release of information about the shooting, and especially the anonymity granted to the officer, has stoked frustrations in this largely African-American community north of St. Louis, where residents describe increasingly tense relations with the police.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: A New Kind of E-Commerce Adds a Personal Touch
articles.snippet: Online ventures, and some brick-and-mortar retailers, are combining data with human interaction for those who find the Internet and malls impersonal.
articles.abstract: Online ventures, and some brick-and-mortar retailers, are combining data with human interaction for those who find the Internet and malls impersonal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Katrina Lake is staring at the ceiling, trying to remember the last time she bought clothes in a store.

articles.headline: Investors Profit From Foreclosure Risk on Home Mortgages
articles.snippet: The recovery in housing is creating a market for bonds that are backed by the mortgages on homes on the verge of foreclosure.
articles.abstract: The recovery in housing is creating a market for bonds that are backed by the mortgages on homes on the verge of foreclosure.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rises in housing prices have been profitable to private equity firms and institutional investors that bought foreclosed homes to flip them or to rent them out. Now the recovery in housing is fueling a niche market for newly minted bonds that are backed by the most troubled mortgages of them all: those on homes on the verge of foreclosure.

articles.headline: As Ebola’s Toll Rises, Drug Makers Race to Test Medicines
articles.snippet: Options include experimental treatments that have never before been tested on people and some of the world’s most widely used drugs.
articles.abstract: Options include experimental treatments that have never before been tested on people and some of the world’s most widely used drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Because outbreaks are sporadic and mainly confined to Africa, the Ebola virus has not been a priority for profit-seeking pharmaceutical companies.

articles.headline: Is This Island Big Enough for Clinton and Obama?
articles.snippet: As Hillary Rodham Clinton met admirers on Martha’s Vineyard, she also faced a tense political moment with President Obama, whose orbit she has moved away from.
articles.abstract: As Hillary Rodham Clinton met admirers on Martha’s Vineyard, she also faced a tense political moment with President Obama, whose orbit she has moved away from.
articles.lead_paragraph: VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass. — Hillary Rodham Clinton blew into this tiny island town like a fast-moving hurricane on Wednesday, creating a commotion at the Bunch of Grapes bookstore, where hundreds of admirers waited for hours in the rain for a glimpse of the woman who they hope will be the next president.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Jonathan Martin and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: New Tack on Unrest Eases Tension in Missouri
articles.snippet: As the local police prepared to release the name of the officer who fatally shot an unarmed teenager, the Missouri State Highway Patrol took over security in Ferguson.
articles.abstract: As the local police prepared to release the name of the officer who fatally shot an unarmed teenager, the Missouri State Highway Patrol took over security in Ferguson.
articles.lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — President Obama on Thursday called for an end to the violence here, denouncing actions both by the police and by protesters. Hours later, the Missouri governor, Jay Nixon, ordered the state highway patrol to take over security operations from local law enforcement.
articles.byline: By John Schwartz, Michael D. Shear and Michael Paulson
